fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: '''Asociația Club Sportiv Progresul Pecica''', commonly known as '''ACS Progresul Pecica''', '''Progresul Pecica''', or simply as '''Pecica''' is a [[Romania]]n professional [[football (soccer)

Progresul Pecica was founded in 1949, under the name of ''Steaua Roșie Pecica'', as a result of the merger between ''Virtutea Pecica (est. in 1921)'' and ''Club Atletic Rovine (est. in 1924)''. Steaua Roșie was renamed in 1954 as ''Recolta Pecica'' and since 1965 was known as '''Progresul Pecica''' playing only at the level of the County or Districtual League (4th tier).
Progresul was renamed again in 1987, this time as ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' and started to be financially supported by the Pecica Oil Scaffold. In 1992, former [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]] member ''Petrolul Arad/ Zădăreni (est. 1983)'' merged with ''Aurul Negru Pecica (est. 1949)'' and formed a new entity, West Petrom Arad (Pecica). West Petrom was financially supported by [[Petrom]] and for 10 years (1994–2004) played in the third tier, but with oscillating results.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In 2001, ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' withdrew from the West Petrom Association, changed its name back to '''Progresul Pecica''' and enrolled a senior squad in the [[Liga IV
column3: Arad County]]. Progresul relegated in the [[Liga V
column4: Honor Division]] after only one season, while West Petrom spent three more seasons in the third tier before it was dissolved. Progresul promoted back in the [[Liga IV]] after 2005 and won twice the competition, in 2015 and 2019, but it succeeded to promote in the third tier only in 2019.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: ''AS Virtutea Pecica'' was established on 15 August 1921 and was the first football club of Pecica, just a commune at that time. Virtutea was founded as a sporting and cultural club, in its composition entering three sports sections (football, tennis & table tennis, chess), but also a cultural section (literature), frequented by all the athletes of the club. The management of AS Virtutea was composed of: Prof. Nestor Blaga, Ioan Gh. Pălincaș, priest Teodor Șiclovan (honorary presidents), Dr. Tyurovschi (president), Augustin Bochiș (secretary) A.M. Iobb (cashier) and Dr. Olteanu (sporting director). Board members were: R. Ponta, Florea Locușteanu, Roman Jugu, E. Ponta and Aron Șiclovan. It is worth mentioning that A.S. Virtutea Pecica had legal personality.<ref name=\"monografieRO\">{{cite web
Among the sports sections that had results at the level of [[Arad County]], was also the football team, which was in the first part of the standings. During the [[1946–47 Divizia C
Taekwondo competition}}: 1946–47]] season, the football section of AS Virtutea activated in the third tier, [[Liga III
column3: Divizia C]]. One of the notable results obtained in this period was a 1–1 draw, in a match played against the former champion of Romania, [[FC Ripensia Timișoara
column4: Ripensia Timișoara]]. These results were obtained with the following players: Alexandru Toth, Ioan Rotariu, Roman Teretean, Ștefan Ponta, Licu Igrișan, Alexandru Molnar, Gheorghe Ponta, Ilie Solomie, Mircea Popețiu, Rudolf Rutz, Iuliu Stainer, Liviu Barbu, Roman Rusu, Cornel Curea, Nicolae Grozav and Gheorge Haș. In the 1948–49 season of the districtual football championship (4th tier), Virtutea was ranked 3rd at the end of the first part of the season. In this edition, the championship included the following members: [[Vagonul Arad]], Patria Chișineu-Criș, Unirea Arad, Olimpia Arad, [[CS Șoimii Pâncota
column5: Șoimii Pâncota]], Tricolorul Arad, Unirea Sântana, Frontiera Curtici, [[CS Național Sebiș
column6: Sebișana Sebiș]], ''Club Atletic Rovine (Pecica)'', S.G. Arad, Găiana Arad and [[CS Șoimii Lipova
column7: Șoimii Lipova]]. In addition to the domestic championship, friendly international matches were played against B.T.K. Battonya and Makó, both clubs from [[Hungary]].<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: During this period, another club was active around the commune of Pecica, ''Club Atletic Rovine'' or ''Rovine Atletikai Club''. Club Atletic was established in 1924 and was the [[Sports club
Taekwondo competition}}: multi-sport]] club of the neighboring commune, Rovine, also the football club of the [[Hungary
column8: accessdate=8 April 2020}}</ref> The club had only two sections (football, tennis & table tennis) and played only in the districtual championship (4th tier). In first part of the 1948–49 season AC Rovine was ranked 11th of 14, with the following ranking line: 13 (matches) 4 (wins) 1 (draw) 8 (losses) 23 (goals scored) 34 (goals conceded) and 9 (points). The club management included the following members: Pál Zvér, Miklós Gergely, Pál Kabát, Mihály Fais and Mihály Lelik, among others. From the long list of players who played for Club Atletic Rovine, these were the most notable: János Kovács (Kudel), József Jován, Mihály Magyar, József Szanda, András Hegedűs, József Szomorú, Dezső and Mihály Nagy-György.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In 1949, the two sports societies based in Pecica (Virtutea) and Rovine (Club Atletic) merged and formed a new entity, named ''Steaua Roșie Pecica'' (Red Star Pecica).<ref name=\"monografieHU\"/><ref name=\"AMEFA\">{{cite web
column3: title=Remember: ”Cupa de Toamnă” a anului 1949 în districtul Arad
column4: trans-title=Remember: \"Autumn Cup\" of 1949 in Arad district

column5: Progresul Pecica squad in the 1960–61 season.]]

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Steaua Roșie Pecica played in four seasons at the level of the 4th tier and was one of the most important clubs from the Arad District.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> In 1954, Steaua Roșie was renamed as ''Recolta Pecica'' and continued to play under this name, but at the same level.<ref name=\"monografieHU\"/>

In 1960, commune of Pecica and commune of Rovine merged, then forming commune of Pecica, one of the biggest communes in the country, at that time, then starting with 1965, a new administrative-territorial division has been implemented in Romania and a new district was founded, Pecica district. Recolta was renamed as '''Progresul Pecica''' in 1960 and activated for next years in the Banat regional championship (4th tier), with remarkable results.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

Even though Progresul Pecica was recognized as an uncomfortable team, it was unable to overcome its condition in the following years, continuing to evolve only in the 4th division.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> However, in 1968 the youth academy of Progresul was opened and in only three years of activity, under the lead of some former important footballers, such as [[Sándor Schwartz]], Ștefan Dobra or Dușan Gavrilovici, but also with the collaboration of some local coaches, such as Romul Popețiu, Matei Kocsik or Silviu Frățilă, Progresul's Academy managed to propose some interesting players for the upper levels. The academy was dissolved in 1971 following political pressures, in that period the plan was that the county must have only a good football team and only one important academy, thus all forces had to be concentrated towards [[FC UTA Arad
Taekwondo competition}}: UTA Arad]], the most successful club of the county.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Supported financially and politically only at the level of the commune, Progresul continued to play for the next 21 years in the Arad County League (4th division), with no notable results. In 1987, Progresul Pecica was renamed again, this time as ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' (Black Gold Pecica) and from that moment, the team started to be financially supported by the Pecica Oil Scaffold.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> But the new investments did not bring the much-anticipated promotion and Aurul Negru remained at amateur level.
On the other hand, in the neighboring commune of [[Zădăreni]], a football team founded in 1983 under the name of ''Petrolul Arad'' succeeded a fast ascension, promoting to [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]] at the end of the 1987–88 season, with, much later well known, [[Ionuț Popa]] as a player and manager.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\">{{cite web
column4: title=Legende ale fotbalului amefist: Mihai Corsenți
column5: trans-title=Legends of the amefist football: Mihai Corsenți
column7: accessdate=8 April 2020}}</ref> Petrolul managed to avoid relegation for three consecutive seasons achieving the following rankings: 6th of 16 ([[1988–89 Divizia C

Taekwondo competition}}: 1991–92]] season, Petrolul withdrew from Divizia C due to certain financial problems and misunderstandings at local level.<ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/><ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/>

column5: West Petrom squad in the 1993–94 season.]]

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In the summer of 1992, the two teams, more or less financially supported by [[Petrom]], ''Petrolul Arad (Zădăreni)'' and ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' merged and formed a new entity, ''West Petrom Arad'', also known as ''West Petrom Pecica''.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/> The new formed entity was mainly the successor of Aurul Negru Pecica. This conclusion is resulting from certain organizational details, such as the club's colors (yellow and blue), home ground ([[Stadionul Progresul (Pecica)
Taekwondo competition}}: Progresul Stadium]], renamed as Petrom Stadium and located in [[Pecica]]), the logo of the new entity (mainly yellow and blue, with an oil scaffold, the name \"West Petrom Pecica\" and 1924 as the year of foundation, which was the year of the establishment of Club Atletic Rovine, one of the Aurul Negru's parent clubs) and also enrolling in the [[Liga IV
column3: Divizia D]] on the place of Aurul Negru.<ref>{{cite web

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In the first season, 1992–93, \"the Oilmen\" were overtaken by CPL Arad, who then promoted to [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]], but in the following season, 1993–94, West Petrom Pecica became the champion of [[Liga IV
column4: Arad County]] and played in the promotion play-off. Although it does not won the play-off, West Petrom Pecica reached Divizia C due to the merger between [[Vagonul Arad
column5: Astra Arad]] and Aris Arad, merge that had as result the club named [[Vagonul Arad
column6: FC Arad]], \"pecicanii\" receiving the vacant place.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/><ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/> Formally, FC Arad was the legal successor of Astra Arad and West Petrom received the place of Aris (former Strungul), club which was absorbed in the merging process.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/> Apart from the title of county champion, West Petrom Pecica also won the preliminary round (Arad County round) of [[Cupa României]]. In the final, disputed on 23 June 1994, in [[Zăbrani]], West Petrom Pecica defeated Mureșul Zădăreni (the new team of Zădăreni, after the leaving of Petrolul to Pecica) with the score of 4–2.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: West Petrom Arad (Pecica) played for 10 years at the level of the third tier. This period was by far the best in the history of local football, despite the fact that West Petrom was an unpredictable team, often oscillating in results. At the end of the first season, \"the Oilmen\" were ranked 14th of 20th, in the following season their results getting better, 9th of 20, but just to be ranked 15th of 19 at the end of the [[1996–97 Divizia C
Taekwondo competition}}: 1996–97]] edition.<ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/> Starting with the [[1997–98 Divizia C
column3: 1997–98]] season, West Petrom it became an uncomfortable team for the rivals, hard to beat, and their rankings were mainly in the top of the standings. West Petrom finished in the late 1990s on the following positions: 5th ([[1997–98 Divizia C

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The apogee moment of the football from Pecica was on 21 September 1999, when Petrom Stadium hosted the encounter between West Petrom Pecica and the most titled team in [[Romania]], [[FC Steaua București
Taekwondo competition}}: Steaua București]]. At the match assisted 5–6,000 supporters (the capacity of the stadium was only 2,500) and was part of the [[1999–2000 Cupa României]], Round of 32.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> Steaua with a squad managed by [[Emerich Jenei]] and formed of playes such as: [[Martin Tudor]], [[Laurențiu Reghecampf]], [[Iulian Miu]], [[Eric Lincar]], [[Eugen Trică]], [[Laurențiu Roșu]] or [[Cristian Ciocoiu]], among others, won with the score of 1–0. In the West Petrom's squad entered the following players: Țapoș – V. Tofaș, Arman, Bene, Hardălău, Varga, R. Gerge, Balaș, Balaj, Ștefăligă and Toderaș, manager Gian Pio del Monaco.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The beginning of the 2000s also meant the regress of West Petrom, club which was ranked only 10th of 15, at the end of the [[2000–01 Divizia C

column3: Arad]] to [[Pecica]], but at the end of the season was ranked only 13th of 16.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/><ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/> Also this season is an important turning point for the future, as it was known, ''West Petrom Arad (Pecica)'' was founded in 1992 by the merger between ''Petrolul Arad (Zădăreni)'' and ''Aurul Negru Pecica'', only that in the same summer in which West Petrom was moved legally to Pecica, the local government withdrew ''Aurul Negru'' from the business and enrolled the team in the [[Liga IV

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In this way it practically came to the original situation, precisely from 1924, when in Pecica were existing two fotball clubs. If in that period the supremacy was divided between Virtutea Pecica and Club Atletic Rovine, now West Petrom Pecica and Progresul Pecica were the contestants. The situation was in fact not great, Progresul relegated in the 5th tier at the end of the 2001–02 season and West Petrom played for three more seasons in the [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]], but with no notable results, [[Petrom]] withdrew its sponsorship and the team was dissolved.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/><ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: '''Asociația Club Sportiv Progresul Pecica''', commonly known as '''ACS Progresul Pecica''', '''Progresul Pecica''', or simply as '''Pecica''' is a [[Romania]]n professional [[football (soccer)

Progresul Pecica was founded in 1949, under the name of ''Steaua Roșie Pecica'', as a result of the merger between ''Virtutea Pecica (est. in 1921)'' and ''Club Atletic Rovine (est. in 1924)''. Steaua Roșie was renamed in 1954 as ''Recolta Pecica'' and since 1965 was known as '''Progresul Pecica''' playing only at the level of the County or Districtual League (4th tier).
Progresul was renamed again in 1987, this time as ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' and started to be financially supported by the Pecica Oil Scaffold. In 1992, former [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]] member ''Petrolul Arad/ Zădăreni (est. 1983)'' merged with ''Aurul Negru Pecica (est. 1949)'' and formed a new entity, West Petrom Arad (Pecica). West Petrom was financially supported by [[Petrom]] and for 10 years (1994–2004) played in the third tier, but with oscillating results.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In 2001, ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' withdrew from the West Petrom Association, changed its name back to '''Progresul Pecica''' and enrolled a senior squad in the [[Liga IV
column3: Arad County]]. Progresul relegated in the [[Liga V
column4: Honor Division]] after only one season, while West Petrom spent three more seasons in the third tier before it was dissolved. Progresul promoted back in the [[Liga IV]] after 2005 and won twice the competition, in 2015 and 2019, but it succeeded to promote in the third tier only in 2019.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: ''AS Virtutea Pecica'' was established on 15 August 1921 and was the first football club of Pecica, just a commune at that time. Virtutea was founded as a sporting and cultural club, in its composition entering three sports sections (football, tennis & table tennis, chess), but also a cultural section (literature), frequented by all the athletes of the club. The management of AS Virtutea was composed of: Prof. Nestor Blaga, Ioan Gh. Pălincaș, priest Teodor Șiclovan (honorary presidents), Dr. Tyurovschi (president), Augustin Bochiș (secretary) A.M. Iobb (cashier) and Dr. Olteanu (sporting director). Board members were: R. Ponta, Florea Locușteanu, Roman Jugu, E. Ponta and Aron Șiclovan. It is worth mentioning that A.S. Virtutea Pecica had legal personality.<ref name=\"monografieRO\">{{cite web
Among the sports sections that had results at the level of [[Arad County]], was also the football team, which was in the first part of the standings. During the [[1946–47 Divizia C
Taekwondo competition}}: 1946–47]] season, the football section of AS Virtutea activated in the third tier, [[Liga III
column3: Divizia C]]. One of the notable results obtained in this period was a 1–1 draw, in a match played against the former champion of Romania, [[FC Ripensia Timișoara
column4: Ripensia Timișoara]]. These results were obtained with the following players: Alexandru Toth, Ioan Rotariu, Roman Teretean, Ștefan Ponta, Licu Igrișan, Alexandru Molnar, Gheorghe Ponta, Ilie Solomie, Mircea Popețiu, Rudolf Rutz, Iuliu Stainer, Liviu Barbu, Roman Rusu, Cornel Curea, Nicolae Grozav and Gheorge Haș. In the 1948–49 season of the districtual football championship (4th tier), Virtutea was ranked 3rd at the end of the first part of the season. In this edition, the championship included the following members: [[Vagonul Arad]], Patria Chișineu-Criș, Unirea Arad, Olimpia Arad, [[CS Șoimii Pâncota
column5: Șoimii Pâncota]], Tricolorul Arad, Unirea Sântana, Frontiera Curtici, [[CS Național Sebiș
column6: Sebișana Sebiș]], ''Club Atletic Rovine (Pecica)'', S.G. Arad, Găiana Arad and [[CS Șoimii Lipova
column7: Șoimii Lipova]]. In addition to the domestic championship, friendly international matches were played against B.T.K. Battonya and Makó, both clubs from [[Hungary]].<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: During this period, another club was active around the commune of Pecica, ''Club Atletic Rovine'' or ''Rovine Atletikai Club''. Club Atletic was established in 1924 and was the [[Sports club
Taekwondo competition}}: multi-sport]] club of the neighboring commune, Rovine, also the football club of the [[Hungary
column8: accessdate=8 April 2020}}</ref> The club had only two sections (football, tennis & table tennis) and played only in the districtual championship (4th tier). In first part of the 1948–49 season AC Rovine was ranked 11th of 14, with the following ranking line: 13 (matches) 4 (wins) 1 (draw) 8 (losses) 23 (goals scored) 34 (goals conceded) and 9 (points). The club management included the following members: Pál Zvér, Miklós Gergely, Pál Kabát, Mihály Fais and Mihály Lelik, among others. From the long list of players who played for Club Atletic Rovine, these were the most notable: János Kovács (Kudel), József Jován, Mihály Magyar, József Szanda, András Hegedűs, József Szomorú, Dezső and Mihály Nagy-György.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In 1949, the two sports societies based in Pecica (Virtutea) and Rovine (Club Atletic) merged and formed a new entity, named ''Steaua Roșie Pecica'' (Red Star Pecica).<ref name=\"monografieHU\"/><ref name=\"AMEFA\">{{cite web
column3: title=Remember: ”Cupa de Toamnă” a anului 1949 în districtul Arad
column4: trans-title=Remember: \"Autumn Cup\" of 1949 in Arad district

column5: Progresul Pecica squad in the 1960–61 season.]]

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Steaua Roșie Pecica played in four seasons at the level of the 4th tier and was one of the most important clubs from the Arad District.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> In 1954, Steaua Roșie was renamed as ''Recolta Pecica'' and continued to play under this name, but at the same level.<ref name=\"monografieHU\"/>

In 1960, commune of Pecica and commune of Rovine merged, then forming commune of Pecica, one of the biggest communes in the country, at that time, then starting with 1965, a new administrative-territorial division has been implemented in Romania and a new district was founded, Pecica district. Recolta was renamed as '''Progresul Pecica''' in 1960 and activated for next years in the Banat regional championship (4th tier), with remarkable results.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

Even though Progresul Pecica was recognized as an uncomfortable team, it was unable to overcome its condition in the following years, continuing to evolve only in the 4th division.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> However, in 1968 the youth academy of Progresul was opened and in only three years of activity, under the lead of some former important footballers, such as [[Sándor Schwartz]], Ștefan Dobra or Dușan Gavrilovici, but also with the collaboration of some local coaches, such as Romul Popețiu, Matei Kocsik or Silviu Frățilă, Progresul's Academy managed to propose some interesting players for the upper levels. The academy was dissolved in 1971 following political pressures, in that period the plan was that the county must have only a good football team and only one important academy, thus all forces had to be concentrated towards [[FC UTA Arad
Taekwondo competition}}: UTA Arad]], the most successful club of the county.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Supported financially and politically only at the level of the commune, Progresul continued to play for the next 21 years in the Arad County League (4th division), with no notable results. In 1987, Progresul Pecica was renamed again, this time as ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' (Black Gold Pecica) and from that moment, the team started to be financially supported by the Pecica Oil Scaffold.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> But the new investments did not bring the much-anticipated promotion and Aurul Negru remained at amateur level.
On the other hand, in the neighboring commune of [[Zădăreni]], a football team founded in 1983 under the name of ''Petrolul Arad'' succeeded a fast ascension, promoting to [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]] at the end of the 1987–88 season, with, much later well known, [[Ionuț Popa]] as a player and manager.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\">{{cite web
column4: title=Legende ale fotbalului amefist: Mihai Corsenți
column5: trans-title=Legends of the amefist football: Mihai Corsenți
column7: accessdate=8 April 2020}}</ref> Petrolul managed to avoid relegation for three consecutive seasons achieving the following rankings: 6th of 16 ([[1988–89 Divizia C

Taekwondo competition}}: 1991–92]] season, Petrolul withdrew from Divizia C due to certain financial problems and misunderstandings at local level.<ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/><ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/>

column5: West Petrom squad in the 1993–94 season.]]

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In the summer of 1992, the two teams, more or less financially supported by [[Petrom]], ''Petrolul Arad (Zădăreni)'' and ''Aurul Negru Pecica'' merged and formed a new entity, ''West Petrom Arad'', also known as ''West Petrom Pecica''.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/> The new formed entity was mainly the successor of Aurul Negru Pecica. This conclusion is resulting from certain organizational details, such as the club's colors (yellow and blue), home ground ([[Stadionul Progresul (Pecica)
Taekwondo competition}}: Progresul Stadium]], renamed as Petrom Stadium and located in [[Pecica]]), the logo of the new entity (mainly yellow and blue, with an oil scaffold, the name \"West Petrom Pecica\" and 1924 as the year of foundation, which was the year of the establishment of Club Atletic Rovine, one of the Aurul Negru's parent clubs) and also enrolling in the [[Liga IV
column3: Divizia D]] on the place of Aurul Negru.<ref>{{cite web

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In the first season, 1992–93, \"the Oilmen\" were overtaken by CPL Arad, who then promoted to [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]], but in the following season, 1993–94, West Petrom Pecica became the champion of [[Liga IV
column4: Arad County]] and played in the promotion play-off. Although it does not won the play-off, West Petrom Pecica reached Divizia C due to the merger between [[Vagonul Arad
column5: Astra Arad]] and Aris Arad, merge that had as result the club named [[Vagonul Arad
column6: FC Arad]], \"pecicanii\" receiving the vacant place.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/><ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/> Formally, FC Arad was the legal successor of Astra Arad and West Petrom received the place of Aris (former Strungul), club which was absorbed in the merging process.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/> Apart from the title of county champion, West Petrom Pecica also won the preliminary round (Arad County round) of [[Cupa României]]. In the final, disputed on 23 June 1994, in [[Zăbrani]], West Petrom Pecica defeated Mureșul Zădăreni (the new team of Zădăreni, after the leaving of Petrolul to Pecica) with the score of 4–2.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: West Petrom Arad (Pecica) played for 10 years at the level of the third tier. This period was by far the best in the history of local football, despite the fact that West Petrom was an unpredictable team, often oscillating in results. At the end of the first season, \"the Oilmen\" were ranked 14th of 20th, in the following season their results getting better, 9th of 20, but just to be ranked 15th of 19 at the end of the [[1996–97 Divizia C
Taekwondo competition}}: 1996–97]] edition.<ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/> Starting with the [[1997–98 Divizia C
column3: 1997–98]] season, West Petrom it became an uncomfortable team for the rivals, hard to beat, and their rankings were mainly in the top of the standings. West Petrom finished in the late 1990s on the following positions: 5th ([[1997–98 Divizia C

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The apogee moment of the football from Pecica was on 21 September 1999, when Petrom Stadium hosted the encounter between West Petrom Pecica and the most titled team in [[Romania]], [[FC Steaua București
Taekwondo competition}}: Steaua București]]. At the match assisted 5–6,000 supporters (the capacity of the stadium was only 2,500) and was part of the [[1999–2000 Cupa României]], Round of 32.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/> Steaua with a squad managed by [[Emerich Jenei]] and formed of playes such as: [[Martin Tudor]], [[Laurențiu Reghecampf]], [[Iulian Miu]], [[Eric Lincar]], [[Eugen Trică]], [[Laurențiu Roșu]] or [[Cristian Ciocoiu]], among others, won with the score of 1–0. In the West Petrom's squad entered the following players: Țapoș – V. Tofaș, Arman, Bene, Hardălău, Varga, R. Gerge, Balaș, Balaj, Ștefăligă and Toderaș, manager Gian Pio del Monaco.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The beginning of the 2000s also meant the regress of West Petrom, club which was ranked only 10th of 15, at the end of the [[2000–01 Divizia C
Taekwondo competition}}: 2000–01]] season. In the summer of 2001, West Petrom Arad moved also its headquarter from [[Arad, Romania
column3: Arad]] to [[Pecica]], but at the end of the season was ranked only 13th of 16.<ref name=\"monografieRO\"/><ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/> Also this season is an important turning point for the future, as it was known, ''West Petrom Arad (Pecica)'' was founded in 1992 by the merger between ''Petrolul Arad (Zădăreni)'' and ''Aurul Negru Pecica'', only that in the same summer in which West Petrom was moved legally to Pecica, the local government withdrew ''Aurul Negru'' from the business and enrolled the team in the [[Liga IV
column5: Arad County]], under its former name of '''Progresul Pecica'''.<ref>{{cite web

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In this way it practically came to the original situation, precisely from 1924, when in Pecica were existing two fotball clubs. If in that period the supremacy was devided between Virtutea Pecica and Club Atletic Rovine, now West Petrom Pecica and Progresul Pecica were the contestants. The situation was in fact not great, Progresul relegated in the 5th tier at the end of the 2001–02 season and West Petrom played for three more seasons in the [[Liga III
Taekwondo competition}}: Divizia C]], but with no notable results, [[Petrom]] withdrew its sponsorship and the team was dissolved.<ref name=\"AMEFA2\"/><ref name=\"ROSoccer\"/>

column4: Honor Division]] in 2002, where it remained for several years.

-- This is Wikipedia, not a football gazette.
\"'''A Scandal in Belgravia'''\" is the first episode of the second series of the [[BBC]] crime drama series ''[[Sherlock (TV series)
Taekwondo competition}}: Sherlock]]'', which follows the modern-day adventures of [[Sherlock Holmes]], and was first broadcast by [[BBC One]] on 1 January 2012. It was written by co-creator [[Steven Moffat]], and directed by [[Paul McGuigan (filmmaker)
column3: Paul McGuigan]]. The episode was based on \"[[A Scandal in Bohemia]]\", a short story by  [[Arthur Conan Doyle

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The episode depicts Sherlock Holmes' ([[Benedict Cumberbatch]]) confrontation with [[List of Sherlock characters#Irene Adler
Taekwondo competition}}: Irene Adler]] ([[Lara Pulver]]), a [[dominatrix]] who has compromising photographs taken with a female member of the [[British royalty
column3: royal family]]. The photographs are stored inside her [[mobile phone]], along with other valuable information which makes her a target of various political factions. Sherlock spends much of the episode keeping the device out of enemy hands while trying to deduce its password. Besides referring to the Doyle short story, the episode title names [[Belgravia]], a district of London adjacent to the grounds of [[Buckingham Palace]].

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: After its broadcast on BBC One, the episode was given consolidated figures of 10.663 million viewers in the United Kingdom. Critical reactions toward the episode were largely positive, with reviewers praising the writing, acting and direction. The episode sparked controversy for showing the character of Irene Adler in the nude; carefully using camera angles to avoid exposing private areas, [[Watershed (television)
Continuing the ending of [[The Great Game (Sherlock)
Taekwondo competition}}: The Great Game]], [[List of Sherlock characters#Sherlock Holmes
column3: Sherlock Holmes]] ([[Benedict Cumberbatch]]) and [[List of Sherlock characters#Dr. John Watson
column4: John Watson]] ([[Martin Freeman]]) are confronting [[List of Sherlock characters#James 'Jim' Moriarty

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Moriarty intends at first to kill them, but as a phone call interrupts, he changes his mind, and dismisses the snipers.
Holmes has become a minor celebrity after Watson blogs about the cases they solved.
One day, Holmes and Watson are brought to meet [[List of Sherlock characters#Mycroft Holmes
Mycroft reveals that [[List of Sherlock characters#Irene Adler
Taekwondo competition}}: Irene Adler]] ([[Lara Pulver]]), took compromising photographs of herself and a female member of the [[British royalty

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The authority wants to retrieve Adler's [[smartphone]], which contains those photographs.
Holmes and Watson try to get into Adler's home by deception, but she has been expecting them. Holmes meets Adler stark naked leaving him unable to deduce anything about her.
As Watson deliberately triggers the fire alarm, Holmes finds Adler's hidden safe, which Adler has glanced at nervously.

Taekwondo competition}}: CIA]] operatives led by Neilson ([[Todd Boyce]]) break into the house and demand that Holmes open the safe.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Holmes solves the password, and in subsequent chaos, some agents are killed, Holmes gets the phone first, and Adler then sedates Holmes, takes the phone instead, and escapes.
On Christmas Eve, Holmes learns via text message that Adler has sent him her phone.
Considering the phone's importance, Holmes thinks she might die soon.
Indeed, the police find a mutilated body, identified to be Adler.
Later, on New Year's Eve, Watson is taken to see Adler, who is alive and faked her death.
Holmes followed them and learns this, too.
Meanwhile, Neilson's team holds [[List of Sherlock characters#Mrs. Hudson
Taekwondo competition}}: Mrs. Hudson]] ([[Una Stubbs]]) hostage, and Holmes subdues Neilson.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Adler comes, and reveals that she is still being hunted.
She asks Holmes to decipher a code stolen from [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)
Sherlock effortlessly cracks it, revealing it to be [[airline seat]] allocation numbers. Adler conveys this information to Moriarty, who taunts Mycroft Holmes that he (Moriarty) now knows their plan.
A government official brings Holmes to [[London Heathrow Airport

Mycroft confirms that the government had planned to fly a plane full of corpses, so as not to alert the terrorists planning to bomb the plane that they know of their plans, reminiscent of the [[Coventry myth]].
However, as Holmes unwittingly helped Adler (and thus Moriarty) crack the code, the scheme was foiled.
Adler reveals a list of demands to Mycroft, including protection, in exchange for the contents of her phone.
However, Holmes figures out the unlocking password to be \"SHER\", so that words on the screen together reads \"I AM SHER-LOCKED\".
Now without her leverage, Adler pleads for protection, but Sherlock and Mycroft turn her down.
Some months later, Mycroft informs Watson that Adler has been killed by terrorists, but intends to tell Holmes instead that she has entered a [[witness protection]] programme in America.
Holmes asks for Adler's phone, and says that Adler's last text message was \"Goodbye, Mr Holmes\", suggesting her death.
After Watson leaves, in the flashback it is shown that Holmes was disguised as the executioner and had rescued Adler.

column4: Statue of Sherlock Holmes in [[Edinburgh]]. \"A Scandal in Belgravia\" alludes to this 'classic' image of Holmes created by illustrator [[Sidney Paget]].]]

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The episode is based on Arthur Conan Doyle's short story \"[[A Scandal in Bohemia]]\", and also alludes to several other adventures.<ref name=\"wollaston\"/><ref name=\"crompton\">{{cite news
column3: title=The timeless appeal of Holmes's sexy logic
column9: location=London}}</ref> There are humorous references to numerous famous Holmes stories, such as \"[[The Adventure of the Greek Interpreter
column10: The Greek Interpreter]]\" (in this episode, the \"Geek Interpreter\"),<ref name=\"RT\" /> \"[[The Adventure of the Speckled Band
column11: The Speckled Band]]\" (in the episode, the \"Speckled Blonde\"),<ref name=\"crompton\"/> \"[[The Adventure of the Naval Treaty
column12: The Naval Treaty]]\" (in the episode, \"The Navel Treatment\"), \"[[The Adventure of the Illustrious Client
column13: The Illustrious Client]]\" and \"[[The Adventure of the Priory School
column14: The Priory School]]\". One of Watson's blogs is titled \"Sherlock Holmes Baffled\", the same title as a [[Sherlock Holmes Baffled
column15: 1900 silent film]], the first depiction of Holmes on film.<ref>{{cite book
column18: title=Sir Arthur Conan Doyle at the Cinema
column23: page=249}}</ref> Watson reveals his middle name to be Hamish, a nod to [[Dr. Watson#Fictional character biography
column24: Dorothy Sayers' theory]]. Moriarty's text message to Mycroft of \"Dear me, Mr. Holmes. Dear me,\" is the same as his note to Holmes in the epilogue of \"The Valley of Fear\". As Holmes opens Adler's safe, he says \"Vatican cameos\", a reference to a mystery that is mentioned in ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles]]''.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: [[Lara Pulver]] decided to audition for the role of Irene Adler when she read the script shortly after wrapping on the espionage series ''[[Spooks (TV series)
Taekwondo competition}}: Spooks]]'', in which she had played Erin Watts. She was cast after meeting Steven Moffat and reading with Cumberbatch.<ref name=\"pulv-ds\">{{cite web
column3: title='Sherlock' Lara Pulver interview: 'Playing Irene Adler is a privilege'
column9: accessdate=5 January 2012}}</ref> Pulver told website [[Digital Spy]] that Moffat \"had written such a multi-dimensional role that I literally immersed myself in his writing. Everything else went out the window for me, research-wise, other than [the dominatrix angle]. Literally, if you search my computer, you'd think I was a porn star or something!\"<ref name=\"pulv-ds\"/> She says that she found the initial vulnerability when filming the nude scenes \"empowering\" because she was unable to \"hide behind anything – there's no mask. This is me, in the flesh! By the end of take two, it wasn't an issue.\"<ref name=\"pulv-ds\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Musician [[Eos Chater]] worked as Benedict Cumberbatch's violin coach for this episode. Although Chater's playing is on the actual soundtrack, Cumberbatch was required to appear to be an expert violinist. To achieve this, Chater was positioned on set so that she could synchronise her playing with his. She says, \"On set I need to see him; to play when he lifts his violin and stop when he stops. And he needs to see me; to copy my bowings, to ghost what I'm doing. In one scene I have to stand outside on two boxes on a [[scissor lift]], watching him while he watches me out of the window.\"<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=How I taught Sherlock Holmes to play the violin

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: \"A Scandal in Belgravia\" was first broadcast on BBC One on Sunday, 1 January 2012. It received preliminary overnight figures of 8.75 million viewers, with a 30.9 per cent audience share. It is ''Sherlock's'' highest rated episode since the show's first episode, \"[[A Study in Pink]]\", which attracted 7.5 million. The episode won BBC One the timeslot, having drawn more viewers than ''[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)
Taekwondo competition}}: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince]]'' on [[ITV1]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title='EastEnders' Pat death, 'Sherlock' beat 'Harry Potter' ITV premiere
column12: title=BBC1's Sherlock gets back on the case with nearly 9 million viewers
column18: publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]}}</ref> When consolidated final ratings are factored in, the episode saw an increase of almost two million viewers, totalling 10.663 million viewers, making it the fifth most viewed programme for the week.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Weekly Top 10 Programmes (select BBC1 and w/e 1 January 2011)
column26: publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]}}</ref> \"A Scandal in Belgravia\" also saw significant viewings on the catch-up [[internet television]] service [[BBC iPlayer]], with more than 800,000 seeing the episode within 24 hours after its original broadcast,<ref>{{cite web
column34: publisher=[[BBC Magazines]]}}</ref> eventually becoming the most-watched programme of 2012 in May with over 2.5 million requests.<ref>{{cite web
column36: title=Sherlock episode with naked Lara Pulver most watched show on BBC iPlayer
column39: accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref> The episode was later repeated on the digital channel [[BBC Three]] on Saturday, 7 January 2012 from 7pm, which did not censor the nude scenes despite being shown pre-watershed.<ref name=repeat/> The repeat was seen by 883,000 viewers.<ref>{{cite web
column41: title=Weekly Top 10 Programmes (select BBC3 and w/e 8 January 2011)

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The [[British Board of Film Classification]] has awarded the episode a [[British Board of Film Classification#Current certificates
Taekwondo competition}}: 12 certificate]] for \"moderate sex references, violence and threat\".<ref>{{cite web
column6: date=12 December 2011}}</ref> The episode, which is accompanied by an [[audio commentary]] by Cumberbatch, Moffat, Gatiss, Pulver and Vertue, was released with the remainder of the second series in the UK on [[DVD]] and [[Blu-ray disc]] on 23 January 2012.<ref>{{cite web

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In the [[United States]], the episode premiered on the [[Public Broadcasting Service]] (PBS) on 6 May 2012 as part of ''[[Mystery!
Taekwondo competition}}: Masterpiece Mystery!]]''. It was seen live by 3.2 million viewers, and was considered a success by the service as it doubled their average primetime ratings.<ref>{{cite web

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Critical reaction to the episode was largely positive. ''[[The Independent]]''{{'}}s Neela Debnath observed a \"constant stream of comedy that ran alongside the suspense\",<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Review of Sherlock 'A Scandal in Belgravia'
column14: Tom Sutcliffe]], also for ''The Independent'', commends Moffat's \"real poignancy\" and how \"barely a minute passes without a line that's worth making a note of\". Sutcliffe continues to praise \"lovely performances and great writing\", and that \"the whole thing is filmed with such invention\".<ref>{{cite news

Taekwondo competition}}: The Telegraph]]'', asserts that \"Cumberbatch is utterly credible as a man who lives entirely in his cerebellum with little regard for the world outside, make ''Sherlock'' the perfect depiction of Holmes for our times\".<ref name=\"crompton\"/> ''[[Radio Times]]'' writer David Brown agreed, stating that adaptation has the \"heartbeat of Conan Doyle's original\".<ref name=\"RT\">{{cite news
column4: title=A Scandal in Belgravia: full review
column8: date=1 January 2012}}</ref> Crompton further argues that the frequent allusions to the Holmes canon shows how ''Sherlock'' \"revels in its own cleverness\".<ref name=\"crompton\"/> Chris Harvey, also for ''The Telegraph'', wrote, \"We'll be lucky if there's a drama that's as much fun all year, so explaining that it was good, seems somehow superfluous\".<ref>{{cite news
column15: location=London}}</ref> ''The Guardian''{{'}}s Sam Wollaston says that Conan Doyle's original story has \"been Moffatised as well as modernised. He starts off parallel but then wanders off left and right, into international terrorism and CIA plots and complicated conspiracy theories. It's very complicated, I find at times.\"<ref name=\"wollaston\">{{cite news
column23: location=London}}</ref> Wollaston later called it \"a bit of a confusing mish-mash\".<ref>{{cite news
column31: location=London}}</ref> In its otherwise positive review, [[Digital Spy]]'s Morgan Jeffery suggests that \"the resolution to the 'Scandal' case is perhaps a little too far-fetched\".<ref>{{cite news

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Following the episode's broadcast, the tabloid ''[[Daily Mail]]'' reported that Irene Adler's nude scene early in the episode had been met with disapproval from some viewers who were concerned that it had been shown before the 21:00 [[Watershed (television)#United Kingdom
Taekwondo competition}}: watershed]] hour, before which adult-oriented content is not supposed to air.<ref name=DailyMailRaunchy>{{cite news
column5: title=Lara Pulver naked in Sherlock Holmes: BBC under fire for raunchy pre-watershed scenes
column10: date=3 January 2012}}</ref> In the nude scene, camera angles and body posture hide sensitive body parts.<ref name=DailyMailRaunchy/> ''The Guardian'' claimed that there was \"no mystery about the Mail's reaction\", observing that the paper was \"so outraged by the scenes\" that it illustrated its story \"with a big blow-up picture on page 9\".<ref>{{cite news
column11: title=BBC1's Sherlock: no mystery about the Mail's reaction
column15: date=3 January 2012}}</ref> Following the broadcast, a BBC spokesman said: \"We're delighted with the critical and audience response to the first episode, which has been extremely positive, and have received no complaints at this stage.\"<ref>{{cite news
column16: title=Sherlock nudity before the watershed shocks viewers
column21: location=London}}</ref> As of 4 January 2012, the BBC had received 102 complaints \"relating to inappropriate scenes broadcast before the Watershed\", although \"it could not tell when the complaints had been made, or how many came before and after the ''Daily Mail'' story\".<ref name=repeat>{{cite news
column22: title=Sherlock: BBC will not remove nude scenes for 7 pm repeat
column29: location=London}}</ref> The regulator [[Ofcom]] also received 20 complaints about the episode, but they decided that it didn't warrant investigating.<ref>{{citation

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Jane Clare Jones, a doctoral student of [[feminist ethics]] writing in her blog on ''The Guardian''{{'}}s website, criticised episode writer Steven Moffat's representation of Irene Adler, arguing that her sexualisation was a regressive step. She writes, \"While Conan Doyle's original is hardly an exemplar of gender evolution, you've got to worry when a woman comes off worse in 2012 than in 1891.\"<ref name=\"jones\">{{cite news
Taekwondo competition}}: title=Is Sherlock sexist? Steven Moffat's wanton women
column9: accessdate=4 January 2012}}</ref> Jones argues that while Conan Doyle's Adler was a \"[[proto-feminist]]\", Moffat undermined \"her acumen and agency ... Not-so-subtly channelling the spirit of the predatory [[femme fatal]] ''[sic]'', Adler's power became, in Moffat's hands, less a matter of brains, and more a matter of knowing 'what men like' and how to give it to them ... Her masterminding of a cunning criminal plan was, it was revealed late in the day, not her own doing, but dependent on the advice of Holmes's arch nemesis, James Moriarty.\"<ref name=\"jones\"/> However, Laura Pledger of ''[[Radio Times]]'' listed Adler as a strong female television character, writing, \"Not since [[Scarlett O'Hara]] has a woman employed quite so many feminine wiles in pursuit of her ultimate goal – and with such chutzpah it feels churlish to criticise.\"<ref>{{cite web
column16: accessdate=5 May 2012}}</ref> Moffat rejected any suggestion that he or Conan Doyle's creation harboured sexist views, labelling the allegation \"deeply offensive\", and misguided in that the critics had assumed that he was \"presenting the characters as the way it is and the way it ought to be\". But, he says, both Adler and Sherlock \"are clearly defined as deranged – it's love among the mad. He's a psychopath, so is she.\"<ref>{{cite news
column19: title='There is a clue everybody's missed': Sherlock writer Steven Moffat interviewed
column24: accessdate=21 January 2012}}</ref> In another interview with [[WalesOnline]], Moffat says:

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: <blockquote>I think it's one thing to criticise a programme and another thing to invent motives out of amateur psychology for the writer and then accuse him of having those feelings. I think that was beyond the pale and strayed from criticism to a defamation act. I'm certainly not a sexist, a misogynist and it was wrong. It's not true and in terms of the character Sherlock Holmes, it is interesting. He has been referred to as being a bit misogynist. He's not; the fact is one of the lovely threads of the original Sherlock Holmes is whatever he says, he cannot abide anyone being cruel to women – he actually becomes incensed and full of rage.<ref>{{cite news
Taekwondo competition}}: title=Sherlock writer Steven Moffat furious with sexist claim

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In May 2012, the episode won three [[British Academy Television Craft Awards]]. Moffat was awarded the Best Writer category for his work on the episode. In the meantime, Charlie Phillips was awarded in Editing: Fiction and the sound team (John Mooney, Jeremy Child, Howard Bargroff, Doug Sinclair) won Sound: Fiction. The episode managed to win all three Craft categories it was nominated for.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Sherlock, Frozen Planet, Great Expectations share BAFTA Craft honours
column10: title=BAFTA TV Craft Awards 2012 winners - in full
column15: publisher=[[Digital Spy]]}}</ref> The episode was nominated for 13 [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s, including [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Miniseries or Movie
column16: Outstanding Miniseries or Movie]]. Benedict Cumberbatch was nominated for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie
column17: Outstanding Lead Actor in a Miniseries or Movie]] for his portrayal of Sherlock and Martin Freeman was nominated for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or a Movie
column18: Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Miniseries or Movie]] for his portrayal of Watson. Moffat and Paul MacGuigan were also nominated for their [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Writing for a Miniseries, Movie or a Dramatic Special
column19: writing]] and [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Directing for a Miniseries, Movie or a Dramatic Special
column22: title=Sherlock: A Scandal In Belgravia - Emmys
column24: accessdate=July 20, 2012}}</ref> In May 2013, the episode won the [[Edgar Award]] for [[List of Edgar Allan Poe Award for Best Episode in a TV Series winners
column25: Best Episode in a TV Series]].<ref>{{cite web

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Rather than delete these links, please hide them...
\"'''A Scandal in Belgravia'''\" is the first episode of the second series of the [[BBC]] crime drama series ''[[Sherlock (TV series)
Taekwondo competition}}: Sherlock]]'', which follows the modern-day adventures of [[Sherlock Holmes]], and was first broadcast by [[BBC One]] on 1 January 2012. It was written by co-creator [[Steven Moffat]], and directed by [[Paul McGuigan (filmmaker)
column3: Paul McGuigan]]. The episode was based on \"[[A Scandal in Bohemia]]\", a short story by Sir [[Arthur Conan Doyle]].

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The episode depicts Sherlock Holmes' ([[Benedict Cumberbatch]]) confrontation with [[List of Sherlock characters#Irene Adler
Taekwondo competition}}: Irene Adler]] ([[Lara Pulver]]), a [[dominatrix]] who has compromising photographs taken with a female member of the [[British royalty
column3: royal family]]. The photographs are stored inside her [[mobile phone]], along with other valuable information which makes her a target of various political factions. Sherlock spends much of the episode keeping the device out of enemy hands while trying to deduce its password. Besides referring to the Doyle short story, the episode title names [[Belgravia]], a district of London adjacent to the grounds of [[Buckingham Palace]].

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: After its broadcast on BBC One, the episode was given consolidated figures of 10.663 million viewers in the United Kingdom. Critical reactions toward the episode were largely positive, with reviewers praising the writing, acting and direction. The episode sparked controversy for showing the character of Irene Adler in the nude; carefully using camera angles to avoid exposing private areas, [[Watershed (television)
Continuing the ending of [[The Great Game (Sherlock)
Taekwondo competition}}: The Great Game]], [[List of Sherlock characters#Sherlock Holmes
column3: Sherlock Holmes]] ([[Benedict Cumberbatch]]) and [[List of Sherlock characters#Dr. John Watson
column4: John Watson]] ([[Martin Freeman]]) are confronting [[List of Sherlock characters#James 'Jim' Moriarty

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Moriarty intends at first to kill them, but as a phone call interrupts, he changes his mind, and dismisses the snipers.
Holmes has become a minor celebrity after Watson blogs about the cases they solved.
One day, Holmes and Watson are brought to meet [[List of Sherlock characters#Mycroft Holmes
Mycroft reveals that [[List of Sherlock characters#Irene Adler
Taekwondo competition}}: Irene Adler]] ([[Lara Pulver]]), took compromising photographs of herself and a female member of the [[British royalty

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The authority wants to retrieve Adler's [[smartphone]], which contains those photographs.
Holmes and Watson try to get into Adler's home by deception, but she has been expecting them. Holmes meets Adler stark naked leaving him unable to deduce anything about her.
As Watson deliberately triggers the fire alarm, Holmes finds Adler's hidden safe, which Adler has glanced at nervously.

Taekwondo competition}}: CIA]] operatives led by Neilson ([[Todd Boyce]]) break into the house and demand that Holmes open the safe.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Holmes solves the password, and in subsequent chaos, some agents are killed, Holmes gets the phone first, and Adler then sedates Holmes, takes the phone instead, and escapes.
On Christmas Eve, Holmes learns via text message that Adler has sent him her phone.
Considering the phone's importance, Holmes thinks she might die soon.
Indeed, the police find a mutilated body, identified to be Adler.
Later, on New Year's Eve, Watson is taken to see Adler, who is alive and faked her death.
Holmes followed them and learns this, too.
Meanwhile, Neilson's team holds [[List of Sherlock characters#Mrs. Hudson
Taekwondo competition}}: Mrs. Hudson]] ([[Una Stubbs]]) hostage, and Holmes subdues Neilson.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Adler comes, and reveals that she is still being hunted.
She asks Holmes to decipher a code stolen from [[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)
Sherlock effortlessly cracks it, revealing it to be [[airline seat]] allocation numbers. Adler conveys this information to Moriarty, who taunts Mycroft Holmes that he (Moriarty) now knows their plan.
A government official brings Holmes to [[London Heathrow Airport

Mycroft confirms that the government had planned to fly a plane full of corpses, so as not to alert the terrorists planning to bomb the plane that they know of their plans, reminiscent of the [[Coventry myth]].
However, as Holmes unwittingly helped Adler (and thus Moriarty) crack the code, the scheme was foiled.
Adler reveals a list of demands to Mycroft, including protection, in exchange for the contents of her phone.
However, Holmes figures out the unlocking password to be \"SHER\", so that words on the screen together reads \"I AM SHER-LOCKED\".
Now without her leverage, Adler pleads for protection, but Sherlock and Mycroft turn her down.
Some months later, Mycroft informs Watson that Adler has been killed by terrorists, but intends to tell Holmes instead that she has entered a [[witness protection]] programme in America.
Holmes asks for Adler's phone, and says that Adler's last text message was \"Goodbye, Mr Holmes\", suggesting her death.
After Watson leaves, in the flashback it is shown that Holmes was disguised as the executioner and had rescued Adler.

column4: Statue of Sherlock Holmes in [[Edinburgh]]. \"A Scandal in Belgravia\" alludes to this 'classic' image of Holmes created by illustrator [[Sidney Paget]].]]

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The episode is based on Arthur Conan Doyle's short story \"[[A Scandal in Bohemia]]\", and also alludes to several other adventures.<ref name=\"wollaston\"/><ref name=\"crompton\">{{cite news
column3: title=The timeless appeal of Holmes's sexy logic
column9: location=London}}</ref> There are humorous references to numerous famous Holmes stories, such as \"[[The Adventure of the Greek Interpreter
column10: The Greek Interpreter]]\" (in this episode, the \"Geek Interpreter\"),<ref name=\"RT\" /> \"[[The Adventure of the Speckled Band
column11: The Speckled Band]]\" (in the episode, the \"Speckled Blonde\"),<ref name=\"crompton\"/> \"[[The Adventure of the Naval Treaty
column12: The Naval Treaty]]\" (in the episode, \"The Navel Treatment\"), \"[[The Adventure of the Illustrious Client
column13: The Illustrious Client]]\" and \"[[The Adventure of the Priory School
column14: The Priory School]]\". One of Watson's blogs is titled \"Sherlock Holmes Baffled\", the same title as a [[Sherlock Holmes Baffled
column15: 1900 silent film]], the first depiction of Holmes on film.<ref>{{cite book
column18: title=Sir Arthur Conan Doyle at the Cinema
column23: page=249}}</ref> Watson reveals his middle name to be Hamish, a nod to [[Dr. Watson#Fictional character biography
column24: Dorothy Sayers' theory]]. Moriarty's text message to Mycroft of \"Dear me, Mr. Holmes. Dear me,\" is the same as his note to Holmes in the epilogue of \"The Valley of Fear\". As Holmes opens Adler's safe, he says \"Vatican cameos\", a reference to a mystery that is mentioned in ''[[The Hound of the Baskervilles]]''.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: [[Lara Pulver]] decided to audition for the role of Irene Adler when she read the script shortly after wrapping on the espionage series ''[[Spooks (TV series)
Taekwondo competition}}: Spooks]]'', in which she had played Erin Watts. She was cast after meeting Steven Moffat and reading with Cumberbatch.<ref name=\"pulv-ds\">{{cite web
column3: title='Sherlock' Lara Pulver interview: 'Playing Irene Adler is a privilege'
column9: accessdate=5 January 2012}}</ref> Pulver told website [[Digital Spy]] that Moffat \"had written such a multi-dimensional role that I literally immersed myself in his writing. Everything else went out the window for me, research-wise, other than [the dominatrix angle]. Literally, if you search my computer, you'd think I was a porn star or something!\"<ref name=\"pulv-ds\"/> She says that she found the initial vulnerability when filming the nude scenes \"empowering\" because she was unable to \"hide behind anything – there's no mask. This is me, in the flesh! By the end of take two, it wasn't an issue.\"<ref name=\"pulv-ds\"/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Musician [[Eos Chater]] worked as Benedict Cumberbatch's violin coach for this episode. Although Chater's playing is on the actual soundtrack, Cumberbatch was required to appear to be an expert violinist. To achieve this, Chater was positioned on set so that she could synchronise her playing with his. She says, \"On set I need to see him; to play when he lifts his violin and stop when he stops. And he needs to see me; to copy my bowings, to ghost what I'm doing. In one scene I have to stand outside on two boxes on a [[scissor lift]], watching him while he watches me out of the window.\"<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=How I taught Sherlock Holmes to play the violin

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: \"A Scandal in Belgravia\" was first broadcast on BBC One on Sunday, 1 January 2012. It received preliminary overnight figures of 8.75 million viewers, with a 30.9 per cent audience share. It is ''Sherlock's'' highest rated episode since the show's first episode, \"[[A Study in Pink]]\", which attracted 7.5 million. The episode won BBC One the timeslot, having drawn more viewers than ''[[Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (film)
Taekwondo competition}}: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince]]'' on [[ITV1]].<ref>{{cite web
column4: title='EastEnders' Pat death, 'Sherlock' beat 'Harry Potter' ITV premiere
column12: title=BBC1's Sherlock gets back on the case with nearly 9 million viewers
column18: publisher=[[Guardian Media Group]]}}</ref> When consolidated final ratings are factored in, the episode saw an increase of almost two million viewers, totalling 10.663 million viewers, making it the fifth most viewed programme for the week.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Weekly Top 10 Programmes (select BBC1 and w/e 1 January 2011)
column26: publisher=[[Broadcasters' Audience Research Board]]}}</ref> \"A Scandal in Belgravia\" also saw significant viewings on the catch-up [[internet television]] service [[BBC iPlayer]], with more than 800,000 seeing the episode within 24 hours after its original broadcast,<ref>{{cite web
column34: publisher=[[BBC Magazines]]}}</ref> eventually becoming the most-watched programme of 2012 in May with over 2.5 million requests.<ref>{{cite web
column36: title=Sherlock episode with naked Lara Pulver most watched show on BBC iPlayer
column39: accessdate=8 June 2012}}</ref> The episode was later repeated on the digital channel [[BBC Three]] on Saturday, 7 January 2012 from 7pm, which did not censor the nude scenes despite being shown pre-watershed.<ref name=repeat/> The repeat was seen by 883,000 viewers.<ref>{{cite web
column41: title=Weekly Top 10 Programmes (select BBC3 and w/e 8 January 2011)

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: White County was formed in 1834. It was named for [[Isaac White]] of [[Equality, Illinois
Taekwondo competition}}: Equality]], [[Illinois]] who was killed at the [[Battle of Tippecanoe]] in 1811. White was a Colonel in the Illinois militia, who volunteered to serve as a Private in the Indiana militia in the march against [[Prophetstown State Park
column3: Prophetstown]]. He was placed under the command of Kentucky Maj. [[Joseph Hamilton Daveiss]]. The two exchanged swords in a demonstration of mutual respect at [[Vincennes, Indiana
column4: Fort Vincennes]]. In the [[Battle of Tippecanoe]] they died together and were buried in a common grave at [[Battle Ground, Indiana

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: The county government is a constitutional body, and is granted specific powers by the [[Constitution of Indiana]], and by the [[Indiana Code]].

'''County Council:''' The county council is the legislative branch of the county government and controls all the spending and revenue collection in the county. Representatives are elected from county districts. The council members serve four-year terms. They are responsible for setting salaries, the annual budget, and special spending. The council also has limited authority to impose local taxes, in the form of an income and property tax that is subject to state level approval, excise taxes, and service taxes.<ref name = inc3623>{{cite web

'''Board of Commissioners:''' The executive body of the county is made of a board of commissioners. The commissioners are elected county-wide, in staggered terms, and each serves a four-year term. One of the commissioners, typically the most senior, serves as president. The commissioners are charged with executing the acts legislated by the council, collecting revenue, and managing the day-to-day functions of the county government.<ref name = inc3623/><ref name = inc2102/>

'''Court:''' The county maintains a [[small claims court]] that can handle some civil cases. The judge on the court is elected to a term of four years and must be a member of the Indiana Bar Association. The judge is assisted by a constable who is also elected to a four-year term. In some cases, court decisions can be appealed to the state level [[circuit court]].<ref name = inc2102/>
'''County Officials:''' The county has several other elected offices, including [[sheriff]], [[coroner]], [[auditor]], [[treasurer]], [[Recorder of deeds
column3: surveyor]], and circuit [[court clerk]]. Each of these elected officers serves a term of four years and oversees a different part of county government. Members elected to county government positions are required to declare [[political party
column4: party]] affiliations and to be residents of the county.<ref name = inc2102/>

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Of the 9,741 households, 31.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 56.1% were married couples living together, 9.3% had a female householder with no husband present, 29.7% were non-families, and 24.8% of all households were made up of individuals. The median income for a household in the county was $47,697 and the median income for a family was $52,626. Males had a median income of $39,715 versus $28,880 for females. fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: * 2× [[List of NFL season rushing touchdowns leaders
'''Robert John Riggins''' (born August 4, 1949), nicknamed '''\"The Diesel\"''' and '''\"Riggo\"''', is an American former [[American football
Taekwondo competition}}: football]] [[running back]] who played professionally in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the [[New York Jets]] and [[Washington Redskins]]. He was known for his powerful running style and productivity well into the latter years of his career; in 1983 at age 34, he rushed for an NFL single-season record 24 touchdowns, and again led the league in rushing touchdowns the following season at age 35. Although he had only one [[Pro Bowl]] appearance in his career, Riggins had his greatest success in the [[NFL playoffs
column3: postseason]], and was named the [[Super Bowl MVP
column4: Most Valuable Player]] of [[Super Bowl XVII]] where he scored one touchdown and rushed for 166 yards in a 27-17 win for the [[Washington Redskins]] over the [[Miami Dolphins]]. Riggins was inducted into the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] in 1992.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins was born in [[Seneca, Kansas]] of partial [[Czech people
Taekwondo competition}}: Czech]] ancestry and attended Centralia High School in [[Centralia, Kansas]]. While there, he was a three-sport athlete, earning high school [[All-America]]n recognition in football, all-state honors in basketball and twice winning the Class B [[100-yard dash]] state title.<ref name=capitaljournal>{{cite web
column5: title=Jayhawks to induct Riggins into Ring of Honor

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins' high school is now located on John Riggins Avenue, which runs through a main part of Centralia.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Centralia is town full of pride

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: On October 12, 2012 John with his brothers Frank (Junior) and Bill Riggins were on hand to dedicate the Centralia High School football field renaming it Riggins Field in honoring their parents, Franklin Eugene and Mildred Riggins.  The Pro Football Hall of Fame dedicated a plaque and NFL Films was there to film the event.  The Riggins brothers took center field for the opening coin toss and the Centralia High School Panthers went on to beat the Troy (Kansas) High School Trojans with a final score of 55–0.

column4: title=Centralia & NFL to honor John Riggins Friday in Centralia

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins attended and played [[college football]] at the [[University of Kansas]] for the [[Kansas Jayhawks football
Taekwondo competition}}: Jayhawks]], where he was an [[All-America]]n<ref name=profootballhof>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=June 20, 2008}}</ref> and two-time All-[[Big Eight Conference]] first-team selection.<ref name=capitaljournal />  Riggins led the Jayhawks to a [[Big Eight Conference]] championship win in 1968.<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Focused Jayhawks plan to remain a Big 12 contender

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: During his senior season in 1970, Riggins rushed for 1,131 yards and scored a then school-record 14 touchdowns.<ref name=capitaljournal />  He finished his career with 2,659 rushing yards,<ref name=capitaljournal /> which broke [[Gale Sayers]]'s career rushing record for the school<ref name=profootballhof /> Riggins is now ranked fifth for Kansas' all-time rushing leaders and 14th for total yards.<ref>{{cite web
While at Kansas, Riggins majored in journalism.<ref name=acting>{{cite web

Taekwondo competition}}: drafted]] #6 in the first round of the [[1971 NFL Draft]] by the [[New York Jets]] and as a rookie he became the first Jet to lead the team in both rushing and receiving.<ref name=jetsprofile>{{cite web
column8: archivedate = June 13, 2008}}</ref>  On October 15, 1972, the Jets set a team-record of 333 rushing yards against the [[New England Patriots]], beating them 41–13.<ref name=seventytwo>{{cite web
column11: title=History of the New York Jets: 1972
column14: archivedate = May 16, 2008}}</ref>  Riggins, who had 168 yards, and [[Emerson Boozer]], who had 150 yards, became the only [[running back]] tandem in franchise history who both rushed for 150 yards in a game.<ref name=seventytwo />  Although he missed the final two games in 1972 because of knee surgery, Riggins rushed for 944 yards, four yards less than [[Matt Snell]]'s franchise record.<ref name=jetsprofile />

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins was among the top ten rushers in the [[American Football Conference]] in [[1974 NFL season
Taekwondo competition}}: 1974]] despite missing four games with a shoulder injury.<ref name=jetsprofile />  After only four years with the Jets, he was already the fourth leading rusher in team history with 2,875 yards.<ref name=jetsprofile />  In [[1975 NFL season
column3: 1975]], Riggins became the first player in franchise history to rush for 1,000 or more yards in a season.<ref name=seventyfive>{{cite web
column6: title=History of the New York Jets: 1975
column9: archivedate = May 16, 2008}}</ref>  On December 21, 1975, he ran for 121 yards against the [[Dallas Cowboys]] which gave him 1,005 for the season.<ref name=seventyfive />  In what turned out to be his last season with the Jets, Riggins made his only appearance in the [[1976 Pro Bowl

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins was named the Jets' MVP (now known as the Martin Award) in [[1972 NFL season

Taekwondo competition}}: 1976]], Riggins signed as a [[free agent]] with the [[Washington Redskins]],<ref name=profootballhof /> who offered him a five-year, $1.5 million contract, compared to the $63,000 he earned in his final year with the Jets.<ref name=hickok>{{cite web
column9: archivedate=December 10, 2012 }}</ref>  He was used mostly in short-yardage situations in his first season with Washington and missed much of the [[1977 NFL season
column10: 1977 season]] with a knee injury.<ref name=hickok />  However, he gained more than 1,000 yards each of the next two seasons and was a major part of the Redskins' offense.<ref name=hickok />

Taekwondo competition}}: training camp]] in July 1980, Riggins requested to renegotiate his $300,000-per-year contract and the Redskins refused.<ref name=newyorktimes>{{cite news
column7: date=June 12, 1981}}</ref> He then chose to leave camp and the Redskins placed him on the left camp-retired list, a move that made him ineligible to play for any other team in the league.<ref name=newyorktimes /> Riggins sat out the [[1980 NFL season
column8: 1980 season]]<ref name=profootballhof /> and did not rejoin the Redskins until [[1981 NFL season
column9: 1981]], when new Washington head coach [[Joe Gibbs]] traveled to Kansas to make a peace offering.<ref name=redskinsbook>{{cite news

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: \"He had a [[camouflage]] outfit on\", Gibbs recalled. {{cquote
Taekwondo competition}}: He had been hunting, him and a buddy. He had a beer can in his hand. It was 10 o'clock in the morning and he's meeting his coach for the first time and I'm thinking [sarcastically], 'This guy really impresses me.' But I went in there, and halfway through the conversation he says, 'You need to get me back there. I'll make you famous.<ref name=redskinsbook />

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: I thought to myself, 'Oh, my God, he's an egomaniac.' I thought, 'I'll get him back and then I'll trade him. I'm not putting up with a fruitcake.' So I fly back to Washington, and two days later he calls me. He says, 'Joe, I made up my mind, and I'm going to play next season.' I thought it was great. I've got him back, and I'll trade that sucker. But then he says, 'There's only one thing I want in my contract.' I ask what it was. He says, 'A no-trade clause.'<ref name=redskinsbook />}}
Riggins' return also came at the suggestion of [[Ed Garvey]], who was the executive director of the [[National Football League Players Association
Eleven months after he left, Riggins returned to training camp in 1981 with a new contract,<ref name=hickok /> telling the media \"I'm bored, I'm broke, and I'm back.\"<ref name=newyorktimes />

column6: title=Raiders Dismantle Redskins, Records in Super Bowl, 38-9

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Two other career milestones happened in the 1983 season for Riggins. On November 20, 1983, he set an NFL record by scoring in his 12th consecutive game during a 42–20 win over the [[Los Angeles Rams]].  His record would end at 13 consecutive games the following week.<ref name=history>{{cite web
column7: archivedate = June 13, 2008}}</ref>  Then on December 17, 1983, [[Mark Moseley]] set an NFL kicking record by scoring 161 points in a season, which also made him the league leader in scoring that season.  Riggins, who scored 144 points, was second on the season scoring list.  This was the first time since [[1951 NFL season
column8: 1951]] that the top two scorers in a season played on the same team.<ref name=history />

column4: George Rogers]] as the starter.<ref name=hickok />  He retired after that season.

column7: archivedate = July 23, 2008}}</ref>  Riggins could be heard in the [[Washington, D.C.]] area weekdays from 4-7pm on 94.3 FM, 92.7 FM & 730 AM, [[WXGI]] 950 AM in [[Richmond, Virginia]] and [[WXTG-FM]] 102.1 FM in [[Virginia Beach, Virginia]] and [[WXTG (AM)]] 1490 in [[Hampton, Virginia]].<ref name=espnradio />  The last show of the series aired on its second anniversary, July 18, 2008. With the merger of Triple X into [[WTEM]] to form ''ESPN 980'', Riggins' afternoon show was replaced by WTEM's afternoon drive show, ''The Sports Reporters''.  Riggins stayed with ESPN 980 as a commentator at large.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: On January 3, 2008, Riggins co-hosted the [[2008 Orange Bowl
Taekwondo competition}}: 74th Orange Bowl]] pre-game show. That same night, the [[2008 Kansas Jayhawks football team
column3: Kansas Jayhawks]] defeated the [[Virginia Tech Hokies]] 24–21. It came 39 years after Riggins and the Jayhawks last played in the game in 1969. He offered congratulations to his Alma Mater in his closing comments, saying \"The KU ship's been out at sea since '48. It finally came to port tonight!\"

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: In September 2008 it was announced that Riggins would co-host the program \"Sirius Blitz\" with Adam Schein on Satellite Radio Stations Sirius 124 and XM 105. Riggins has been critical on his radio shows of the current management of the Washington Redskins under owner Dan Snyder.
Previously, he had been a panelist on ''Redskins Report'' until that show was canceled in December 2008 due to budget cuts.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Leonard Shapiro: Loss of Michael Is a Truly Deep Cut

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: [[Category:Players of American football from Kansas]]","{{short description
* 2× [[List of NFL season rushing touchdowns leaders
'''Robert John Riggins''' (born August 4, 1949), nicknamed '''\"The Diesel\"''' and '''\"Riggo\"''', is an American former [[American football
Taekwondo competition}}: football]] [[running back]] who played professionally in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the [[New York Jets]] and [[Washington Redskins]]. He was known for his powerful running style and productivity well into the latter years of his career; in 1983 at age 34, he rushed for an NFL single-season record 24 touchdowns, and again led the league in rushing touchdowns the following season at age 35. Although he had only one [[Pro Bowl]] appearance in his career, Riggins had his greatest success in the [[NFL playoffs
column3: postseason]], and was named the [[Super Bowl MVP
column4: Most Valuable Player]] of [[Super Bowl XVII]] where he scored one touchdown and rushed for 166 yards in a 27-17 win for the [[Washington Redskins]] over the [[Miami Dolphins]]. Riggins was inducted into the [[Pro Football Hall of Fame]] in 1992.

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins was born in [[Seneca, Kansas]] of partial [[Czech people
Taekwondo competition}}: Czech]] ancestry and attended Centralia High School in [[Centralia, Kansas]]. While there, he was a three-sport athlete, earning high school [[All-America]]n recognition in football, all-state honors in basketball and twice winning the Class B [[100-yard dash]] state title.<ref name=capitaljournal>{{cite web
column5: title=Jayhawks to induct Riggins into Ring of Honor

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Riggins' high school is now located on John Riggins Avenue, which runs through a main part of Centralia.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Centralia is town full of pride

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: On October 12, 2012 John with his brothers Frank (Junior) and Bill Riggins were on hand to dedicate the Centralia High School football field renaming it Riggins Field in honoring their parents, Franklin Eugene and Mildred Riggins.  The Pro Football Hall of Fame dedicated a plaque and NFL Films was there to film the event.  The Riggins brothers took center field for the opening coin toss and the Centralia High School Panthers went on to beat the Troy (Kansas) High School Trojans with a final score of 55–0.

column10: 1977 season]] with a knee injury.<ref name=hickok />  However, he gained more than 1,000 yards each of the next two seasons and was a major part of the Redskins' offense.<ref name=hickok />

Taekwondo competition}}: training camp]] in July 1980, Riggins requested to renegotiate his $300,000-per-year contract and the Redskins refused.<ref name=newyorktimes>{{cite news
column7: date=June 12, 1981}}</ref> He then chose to leave camp and the Redskins placed him on the left camp-retired list, a move that made him ineligible to play for any other team in the league.<ref name=newyorktimes /> Riggins sat out the [[1980 NFL season

But I went in there, and halfway through the conversation he says, 'You need to get me back there. I'll make you famous.<ref name=redskinsbook />

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: I thought to myself, 'Oh, my God, he's an egomaniac.' I thought, 'I'll get him back and then I'll trade him. I'm not putting up with a fruitcake.' So I fly back to Washington, and two days later he calls me. He says, 'Joe, I made up my mind, and I'm going to play next season.' I thought it was great. I've got him back, and I'll trade that sucker. But then he says, 'There's only one thing I want in my contract.' I ask what it was. He says, 'A no-trade clause.'<ref name=redskinsbook />}}
Riggins' return also came at the suggestion of [[Ed Garvey]], who was the executive director of the [[National Football League Players Association

fix bold,safe,WOSlinker,"{{short descrip: Two other career milestones happened in the 1983 season for Riggins. On November 20, 1983, he set an NFL record by scoring in his 12th consecutive game during a 42–20 win over the [[Los Angeles Rams]].  His record would end at 13 consecutive games the following week.<ref name=history>{{cite web
column7: archivedate = June 13, 2008}}</ref>  Then on December 17, 1983, [[Mark Moseley]] set an NFL kicking record by scoring 161 points in a season, which also made him the league leader in scoring that season.  Riggins, who scored 144 points, was second on the season scoring list.  This was the first time since [[1951 NFL season
column8: 1951]] that the top two scorers in a season played on the same team.<ref name=history />

column4: George Rogers]] as the starter.<ref name=hickok />  He retired after that season.
